{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2979391,"name":"Matt S","username":"mattsini","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/ed8c4c/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-12-01T20:38:27.697Z","cooked":"

Hi,
Im a mentor for team 5443 and new to programming!
Since our mentor in charge of all the programming has left, I have to learn how to code our robot from scratch (it’s a big challenge)!

So far, I’ve been using JAVA to develop a code for our robot to move using TankDrive. The only problem is that, for the moment, the % output to the motors is 100% which makes the robot hard to pilot. I would like the output to be around 60%-70%. Here’s the code I have to far:

//Right Motors
private final VictorSP rightmotor1 = new VictorSP(0);
private final VictorSP rightmotor2 = new VictorSP(1);

// Left Motors
private final VictorSP leftmotor1 = new VictorSP(3);
private final VictorSP leftmotor2 = new VictorSP(4);

//Speed Controller Groups
private final SpeedControllerGroup rightSpeedGroup = new SpeedControllerGroup(rightmotor1, rightmotor2);
private final SpeedControllerGroup leftSpeedGroup = new SpeedControllerGroup(leftmotor1, leftmotor2);

//drivetrain
DifferentialDrive drivetrain = new DifferentialDrive(rightSpeedGroup, leftSpeedGroup);

//Joystick
Joystick stick = new Joystick(1);

@Override
public void teleopPeriodic() {

drivetrain.arcadeDrive(stick.getY(), stick.getZ());

Thank you in advance,
Matt

You can multiply the joystick inputs by some scale factor (for instance 0.6-0.7 or whatever you want) before passing them into the arcadeDrive function.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2021-12-01T20:52:44.604Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":60,"readers_count":59,"score":37.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":397756,"topic_slug":"output-of-motor-victorsp-pwm","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":45763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6738a | ISR | WPILib"},"post_url":"/t/output-of-motor-victorsp-pwm/397756/2","custom_user_title":"6738a | ISR | WPILib","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2979395,"name":"Andrew McBride","username":"AndrewMcb","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ec9cab/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-12-01T21:09:40.554Z","cooked":"

You have what looks to be a great start!

For what you are trying to achieve, multiplying by some scale is a good option. However, I would argue that just limiting % output is a poor way to move forward. Pushing matches happen regularly, and reducing the power available to the drivers means they will likely be bullied by defense more easily than they otherwise would be.

If the acceleration is the problem that you have, then having some curve that the input follows (making some s curve function that you multiply the raw value by to more smoothly change power at low speeds). Ether had a good post about this: paper: joystick sensitivity (gain) adjustment

If there is a different issue, then I would love to hear more about it so that the community can help work towards a better solution.

Would that look like: drivetrain.arcadeDrive(stick.getY(0.6), stick.getZ(0.));
? Thank you for your insight

Thank you for your reply!

I was thinking about multiplying by a scale (that was our programmer used to do back in the days). The problem is, I don’t know where/how to do it.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2021-12-01T21:16:04.616Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":47,"readers_count":46,"score":14.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":397756,"topic_slug":"output-of-motor-victorsp-pwm","display_username":"Matt S","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":40342,"username":"AndrewMcb","name":"Andrew McBride","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ec9cab/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49961,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/output-of-motor-victorsp-pwm/397756/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2979400,"name":"Andrew McBride","username":"AndrewMcb","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ec9cab/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-12-01T21:21:52.646Z","cooked":"

the WPILib Joystick Class can be found here: Joystick (WPILib API 2021.3.1)

I believe it would look like: drivetrain.arcadeDrive(stick.getY()*0.6, stick.getZ()*0.6);
or you could set the value to multiply by to some constant, and replace it into that.

Finding the scale to multiply by is the hardest part. For ease of use sake, I’m going to choose the function y=x^3, since that hits three critical points that I need, (-1, -1), (0,0), (1,1). For this example, y is equivalent to the adjusted joystick value, and x is equivalent to the raw joystick value. See below for an example of how to do this(keep in mind this is untested, and may run into some issue):
public void teleopPeriodic(){
double yValue = stick.getY()^3;
double zValue = stick.getZ()^3;
drivetrain.arcadeDrive( yValue, zValue);
}

Have a good day!

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2021-12-01T21:37:31.942Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":36,"readers_count":35,"score":12.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":397756,"topic_slug":"output-of-motor-victorsp-pwm","display_username":"Matt S","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49961,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/output-of-motor-victorsp-pwm/397756/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2979405,"name":"Wolly :)","username":"wolly_efendi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wolly_efendi/{size}/165245_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-01T21:37:40.328Z","cooked":"

It would actually be:

drivetrain.arcadeDrive(stick.getY() * 0.6, stick.getZ() * 0.6);

Numbers like this that aren’t defined in the code are called magic numbers. Instead what you want to do for readability and ease of editing later on is to create a variable for each of them:

double ARCADE_Y_SCALE = 0.6;
double ARCADE_Z_SCALE = 0.6;

and then apply them as such:

drivetrain.arcadeDrive(stick.getY() * ARCADE_Y_SCALE, stick.getZ() * ARCADE_Z_SCALE);

Its a good idea to save these numbers in somewhere that makes sense, for example in separate Constants.java file or in the Drivetrain class itself. In order to access these variables publicly, you would use the public, static , and final keywords when initializing the variable. Here’s an example of using these keywords:

public static final double ARCADE_Y_SCALE = 0.6;
public static final double ARCADE_Z_SCALE = 0.6;

The keyword public makes the variable accessible from another file. static is a bit more complex, but essentially you can refer to this method without instantiating its parent class. In practice, you would call it as Constants.ARCADE_Y_SCALE from outside the Constants.java class. final means that this value cannot be edited, so something like this isn’t possible:

public static final ARCADE_Y_SCALE = 0.6;
...
ARCADE_Y_SCALE = 0.7; //Error here, cannot edit a variable that is final

Note that the convention for constants is uppercase and with underscores separating each word in the name.

If there isn’t one already, create an OI.java file and create a bunch of methods to try out different scaling methods: just linear scale (multiplying each value by a constant), a polynomial scale (like @AndrewMcb suggested), etc. Depending on your controller, you can also add a deadband (for some controllers, moving the stick say 5% in one direction or the other doesn’t get registered) so that you only drive the robot between the 5% and 100% window.

As with many things on the software side, you can make it as simple or as complicated as you want. Personally my suggestion would be to get a simple 1:1 drive code working, and then add a slow-speed button on the drive (ie. if this button is pressed, scale the drive speed down to around 60%). Slow-speed is useful for intaking game objects. After this then try out different scaling factors. Don’t jump over the simple implementations to get more complex! If you ever need a hand feel free to shoot me a private message and we can work something out.
